original_data.question: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of nausea for the last two weeks. During this period, she has had increased urinary frequency and fatigue. She also reports two episodes of non-bloody vomiting. There is no personal history of serious illness. Her last menstrual period was 6 weeks ago. Physical examination shows bilateral breast tenderness. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is positive. Which of the following is the most accurate predictor of the gestational age?

options.A: Ratio of head to abdominal circumference

model_response:
The ratio of head circumference to abdominal circumference is the most accurate predictor of the gestational age. This ratio is 1.3 or greater in the 5th month of gestation, 1.0 from the 6th through 9th months, and 0.6 or less in the 10th month. The femoral length is measured from the top of the femur to the upper border of the symphysis pubis. This length is approximately 2/5 of the crown-rump length at the 10th week of gestation. The biparietal diameter is measured by measuring the distance between the two parietal eminences. This diameter is approximately 1/3 of the head circumference. The crown-rump length is the most accurate predictor of the gestational age during the first trimester.

Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.

An unpleasant sensation in the stomach usually accompanied by the urge to vomit. Common causes are early pregnancy, sea and motion sickness, emotional stress, intense pain, food poisoning, and various enteroviruses.
Any period of seven consecutive days.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.
Urination at short intervals; it may result from increased urine formation, decreased bladder capacity, or lower urinary tract irritation.
The state of weariness following a period of exertion, mental or physical, characterized by a decreased capacity for work and reduced efficiency to respond to stimuli.
A noteworthy happening that is distinctive in a series of related events.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
A state of ill health, bodily malfunction, or discomfort.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.

Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Information or variable that supports a probabilistic estimate of future events.

The age of the conceptus, beginning from the time of FERTILIZATION. In clinical obstetrics, the gestational age is often estimated from the onset of the last MENSTRUATION which is about 2 weeks before OVULATION and fertilization. It is also estimated to begin from fertilization, estrus, coitus, or artificial insemination.
